title: Thursday, 17th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:02am

Fingers cross

PM11:02am

Morning

PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

11:02 am
PM11:02am

On shiny refreshed FT Alphaville

PM11:03am

Bear with us today

PM11:03am

Dealing with new stuff

11:03 am
PM11:03am

New format

PM11:03am

Which we will need to get used to

PM11:03am

There will be bugs!

11:04 am
PM11:04am

PM11:04am

Do report anything you see

PM11:05am

We've lost the commenters

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Techies are on the case

PM11:06am

Do try a hard refresh if you are on the right

undefined
11:07 am
PM11:07am

Okay, so as well as the inevitable back and forwards with the tech team this morning

PM11:07am

I also had what I thought was a humdinger of piece of raw

PM11:07am

But I've had to back off it

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Can't share,

PM11:09am

It's tough at the moment with M&A rumours

PM11:09am

Look around the usual purveyors of bid gossip

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Lots and lots of stories turn out to be plain wrong -- or the deals get killed or they are stale or whatever.

PM11:09am

They don't land

PM11:10am

The hacks concerned have to wear all the risk

11:09 am
PM11:10am

Which is uncomfortable

BE11:10am

Yup. It's been the story of 2016, that. Can't tell you how many days I've wasted chasing stuff, then not running it.

BE11:10am

Then seeing it turn up elsewhere a few days or weeks later.

11:10 am
PM11:10am

And shoe leather, schleping to Mayfair

BE11:10am

Hm. That too. I've grown to hate Green Park Station.

BE11:11am

Anyway, rather than spending more time talking about stories we can't talk about, I guess we should talk about stories we can.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

Guess so

PM11:11am

Also jsut want to check with the Rabble on the new design

PM11:11am

Anyone on mobile? Let me know experience

11:11 am
PM11:11am

I said yesterday you couldn't comment on mobile

PM11:12am

ut you can!

PM11:12am

But

11:11 am
undefined
PM11:12am

So...

PM11:12am

Footsie up, a bit

11:12 am
PM11:12am

Bonds mixed

PM11:12am

But have calmed down

BE11:12am

It's kinda dull. That's the upshot. It's a second day of "kinda dull".

11:13 am
BE11:13am

The news folk are talking about removing the Trump widget from the FT front page, which I guess is as good an indicator of a return to normality as any.

PM11:14am

Well, it's accepting the new reality as normality

BE11:14am

W'evs.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

In terms of London movers, there's a few. Royal Mail, for instance.

PM11:15am

Hit hard

Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 463.80, down 35.1 (-7.04%), High: 495.00, Low: 463.40, Volume: 2.88m
11:15 am
PM11:15am

Interims here: http://www.investe...1611170700113991P/

BE11:15am

Guidance not explicitly changed but it's H2 skewed.

BE11:16am

RBC provides as good a summary as any.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Our view - a historical 46%-47% H1 weighting implies FY16/17E EBIT of £680m-£690m vs. RBCe £727m (£732m consensus) - unless cost measures and Parcel performance accelerate strongly in H2 - to offset slowing marketing mail progress: At £320m super-adjusted EBIT, RMG was below our flat (£340m super-adjusted EBIT) expectations for H1-2016/17E, after FX gains in GLS, working day effects and cost measures in UKPIL offset by extra UK NI charges (£70m annualised) and underlying letter mail revenue declines (where the 8% decline in marketing mail is an early GDP warning sign, we think).

BE11:16am

The H1 EBIT represents 44% of FY consensus EBIT (£732m, RBCe £727m). Despite more working days (a +£40m-£45m effect for profit) this looks lower than the past three years' H1 weighting of 46-47% of FY EBIT. H2 tends to be more heavily profit weighted due to higher Christmas Parcel activity, and cal-Q1 (RMG Q4) benefiting from year-end statements in letter mail volumes.

Our risk/reward view - With FY DPS cons 23.2p (interim due 7.4p) then RMG's DPS yield of 4.7% (vs. 10-year UK government bond yields of 1.3%) implies a higher valuation - or expectation of profit growth than the DPS yield/10-year bond yield differentials for Austrian Post 6%/0.3%, bpost 6%/0.4%, Post NL (2017E) 6%/0.3%, and DP-DHL 3.4%/0.3% (but with growth at DHL). We think performance does not suggest a chance of better profit growth at RMG but highlights present risk/reward out of skew with its mail peer group.

BE11:17am

Inflation: RMG needs a new wage agreement for April 2017 onwards - at a point where UK inflation might be accelerating. For the majority of the business the revenue outlook remains hostage to a confused UK macro-political outlook. With relatively limited ability to flex network costs in the short term even a minor UKPIL revenue deviation could create risk to profits. This could occur, for example, if parcel volume growth slowed (and pricing became more diluted) if the UK consumer slows (on squeezed discretionary incomes); or, if advertising mail slows or even falls; or, RMG's price rises lag an accelerating cost inflation backdrop. Overall, this suggests opex pressures, but inflationary effects on higher bond yields may also be helpful to the pension outlook - as the process still sees no new news (but company remarks expect news by financial year end - i.e. March 2018).

Overall, H1-2016/17 saw super-adjusted EBIT down 6.5% at £320m (£342m) (there was no consensus). Looking in detail, H1-2016/17 gained two working days (worth ~£40-£45m EBIT) but lost ~£35m due to NI cost increases, meaning before these factors EBIT fell 8% like-for-like (on our estimates).

11:17 am
BE11:18am

And Goldman.

BE11:18am

Royal Mail reported weaker-than-expected 1H17 results this morning, with
EBIT pre-transformation costs of £320 mn, which came in 13% below our
expectations; EPS of 19.2p was 8% below our estimate and c.4% below
Bloomberg consensus. This was driven by lower-than-expected
profitability in UKPIL. RMG issued guidance of targeting £225 mn in UKPIL
operating cost avoidance in FY17, and increased its cost avoidance target
to £600 mn vs £500 mn previously over the three financial years ending in
FY18. The company also stated that its investment cycle has likely peaked,
expecting net capex of no more than £500 mn pa going forward, compared
with an average of £615 mn over the last three years.

BE11:18am

Overall, we view these results as a mixed bag: while the outlook of
increased cost avoidance and lower capex going forward (which we have
long argued) should be taken positively, 1H appears weaker than expected.
The company is now also excluding the increased costs from contributions
to the new single-tier pension scheme from the underlying cost
movements (£65 mn, or 1.2% of the people costs), which makes y-o-y costs
comparisons to our and consensus expectations less clear at this stage. In
terms of the top line, addressed mail volume declined an implied -6% in
2Q, following -2% in 1Q, which is still in line with RMG’s forecast range of
-4%-6%; parcel volumes were up an implied 2% in 2Q, in line with growth
in 1Q. GLS revenue growth slowed to 5% in 2Q, vs 13% in 1Q, which
however was helped by the timing of Easter.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

We remain Neutral-rated; our 12-month price target is 600p. We value the
core business at 6.5x 2018E EV/EBITDA and add the potential value from the
disposal of its London real estate. Key risks: Upside: Better-than-expected
mail volumes, decreased competition in parcels (both volumes and prices).
Downside: Worse-than-expected volume evolution in mail and parcels,
potential incremental costs for pension contributions (no update there).

BE11:19am

The lack of comment on the pensions is a bit of a frustration ......

PM11:20am

hmm

11:20 am
BE11:20am

............. given it's a quite important part of the RMG investment case. Which is, to summarise: 1. how many postmen can they sack? 2. how much property can they flip; 3. how much do they have to pay their retired postmen? and 4. What dumb stuff might the regulator do?

BE11:21am

I'm still a bit confused as to why this was floated, but let's not head back into that.

undefined
11:21 am
BE11:22am

ROTR, thanks, and keep the redesign comments coming.

BE11:22am

Don't hold back. If you hate it, or anything about it, do please tell us.

BE11:22am

On this side of the page, we'll keep going on the usual stuff.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Virgin Money, for instance.

Virgin Money Holdings (UK) PLC (VM.:LSE): Last: 316.80, down 21.7 (-6.41%), High: 321.70, Low: 310.80, Volume: 71.22m
PM11:23am

Ouch

11:23 am
PM11:24am

Actualy, not ouch

BE11:24am

Wilbur Ross slots for a third and final time.

PM11:24am

Inevitable

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Got it away at 320p?

BE11:24am

Yep. That's 54m shares, 5.5% discount.

BE11:25am

Those buying are already underwater.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

We can go though the usual "positive for liquidity" arguments here ........

BE11:25am

... Or we can let Ian Gordon at Investec go through them.

PM11:25am

Virgin Financial Investments still has just under 35%. That's Branson, right?

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Or Virgin Group

BE11:25am

Yep.

BE11:26am

This increases the free-float to c.65%, leaving only Virgin Group’s 35% stake which, (rightly or wrongly), we assume to be a “quasi-permanent” investment rather than presenting a private equity style “overhang” risk. We see the WL Ross selldown as a technical positive. However, we continue to see considerably greater value in Aldermore (Buy), Shawbrook (Buy) and OneSavings (Buy) despite their recent outperformance.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

This is WL Ross’ third and final placing. Previous selldowns were achieved over 45m shares in April 2015 at 400p (a 5.2% discount) and over 50m shares in September 2015 at 405p (a 4.4% discount). Clearly we do not know the precise rationale for the timing of WL Ross’ exit, though Virgin Money shares have now rallied by 65% from a trough on 205p on 7 July 2016. This reduction in residual upside was the primary reason for our recent (reluctant) downgrade to Hold

PM11:26am

“quasi-permanent” investment rather than presenting a private equity style “overhang” risk. -- famous last words

BE11:27am

......... Surely Branson doesn't need the cash, tho. His personal wealth is positively Trumpian.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Back to Investec.

BE11:27am

Since the previous share placements executed in 2015, Virgin Money has delivered extraordinary levels of growth across its mortgage and card portfolios, helping to drive a sharp improvement in operational efficiency and returns. Recall that, as recently as 2014, Virgin Money recorded a small Attributable Loss. We remain entirely constructive on Virgin’s ability to drive further strong growth in these two core businesses – indeed, we forecast net mortgage growth of £8.2bn (+28%) and cards growth of £1.5bn (+68%) over the next nine quarters, Q4 2016e-Q4 2018e.

BE11:27am

However, we do now see reasons for slight caution. (1) After more than a year of broad stability, Bank of England Quoted Household Interest Rates on a 2-year fixed rate mortgage have fallen sharply from 1.91% in May to 1.51% in October, (2) while the outlook for Net Interest Income remains robust, Virgin Money’s own guidance for Other Income has softened to “flat”, (3) 2017/18e earnings and returns will be reduced by incremental AT1 coupons of c.£16m p.a. (net) and expenditure under the new partnership with 10x Future Technologies, (we assume c.£10m p.a.). Hold rec and 365p TP reaffirmed.

11:28 am
undefined
PM11:28am

Just a quick note on ML transcripts

PM11:29am

You'll see later, if you look, that ROTR comments are interspersed with ROTL

11:29 am
PM11:29am

We've already had some negative feedback on this (and some positive)

PM11:29am

But I'd point out that the comments were generally ignored by those reading transcripts, since you have to keep scrolling up and down to see context

PM11:30am

This is an attempt to solve that problem

11:29 am
PM11:30am

Might not be a solution. You can let us know

PM11:30am

But that's the context for the change

BE11:30am

Yes, do let us know. I'm particularly interested.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

For anyone reading the transcript who might have thoughts: alphaville@ft.com

undefined
PM11:02am

ed

11:32 am
BE11:32am

The BOE's Financial Policy Committee will be given the discretion to introduce LTV restrictions as well as interest coverage limitations.

BE11:33am

We still don't know how these powers might be applied, but will find out shortly.

PM11:33am

This is potentially quite radical

11:33 am
PM11:33am

And possibly problematic

BE11:34am

Depends what you see as a problem. Some see over-levered lightly-regulated BTL mortgages as a problem, and I'm not sure I have a strong argument against that.

BE11:35am

Have some Goodbody ....

11:34 am
BE11:35am

While the Chancellor’s announcement yesterday does not come as a surprise (it
follows a consultation launched by the Treasury in December 2015) it is surely the
final instalment in what has been an annus horribilis for the UK BTL sector –
following the announced reductions in tax relief available, announced stamp duty
increases, and the start of tighter lending restrictions already. The new measures
are likely to further dampen the appetite for BTL investment on the part of
individual landlords (though we expect to see a material increase in the volume of
BTL transactions effected through corporate structures). Interestingly, in this vein,
a survey of almost 1,000 landlords by the Residential Landlords’ Association has
found that c.25% of BTL investors are planning to sell their rental properties as a
result of the tax changes. On a positive note, the release of much-needed supply in
the form of available homes for sale owing to any large-scale landlord retreat from
the market could prove supportive for bank residential mortgage lending flows.

BE11:36am

And, since we're in DPL, Deutsche Bank's Autumn Statement preview for the broader picture.

BE11:36am

London residential:
1) Stamp duty. A cut has been widely speculated. A) A stamp duty ‘holiday’
which helps the low end but has a small impact on higher priced property
would not have a big impact on London. B) A meaningful cut across the board
for all price points (and including investors). This is politically tougher to make
happen but if it is of reasonable size this is a positive for London as stamp duty
is blamed by many for the sluggish market. While this is a sentiment positive
and likely results in a ‘spurt’ in transactions, it does not change affordability
and buy-to-let (BTL) issues, which are our main concerns for London.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

2) Demand support. The London Help-to-buy 40% equity loan scheme
expanded to the whole of the UK new build market (which is currently at 20%).
We do not think that the introduction of this policy is likely and we think
further demand support for London is especially unlikely.

BE11:37am

3) Supply policies/encouraging build rate. Any policies that are perceived to be
successful in increasing build rate/supply would be a medium term negative as
higher supply results in lower pricing. Policies that have been reported in the
press include taxes on land (see below) and a £2bn fund for government
guarantees to housebuilder returns/sales prices. Guarantees could have an
offsetting positive impact as this benefits builders but this ‘guarantee fund’
appears to be relatively small/targeted at smaller builders. The £2bn fund
represents only c.20% of the total end sales value of Earls Court.

BE11:37am

4) Land tax. There have been suggestions of ‘getting housebuilders building’ to
stop them slowing activity. This could mean a tax on land/other incentives to
push housebuilders to build. This would be negative for land values/Capco.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

5) Buy-to-let tax deductibility law repealed/hardened. It is politically difficult to
achieve a ‘tax cut for landlords’ in our view but if it happens it weakens our
arguments on BTL and the impact of new mortgage affordability rules. On the
flip side, buying properties through companies may be roped into the BTL tax
deductibility law, which would be incrementally negative.

BE11:38am

Note also, on the BTL theme, we have Paragon results due November 23.

Paragon Group of Companies Plc (PAG:LSE): Last: 349.60, up 3.8 (+1.10%), High: 351.00, Low: 345.80, Volume: 108.76k
11:39 am
BE11:39am

Though results likely to be dull, or dullish.

undefined
PM11:40am

See vodafone speaking at this TMT conference

11:40 am
PM11:40am

IN barcelona

PM11:41am

Talking down the idea of fresh deals in the sector

PM11:41am

Here's a bit of MOST

11:41 am
PM11:41am

Vodafone's CEO said that its Dutch merger with Ziggo (provisionally approved by EC, Eur 3.5bn of synergies) might not necessarily be a precursor to a wider deal. In contrast, Vodafone noted that a transaction with Liberty might emerge as a counterforce to incumbents that the EC would be pleased with. Telefonica stressed that it is not in any rush to dispose of assets, while also mentioning private interest in its infrastructure company Telxius – while the Spanish PTT is open to exploring alternatives for the UK business. Vodafone´s CEO expects the benefits of consolidation in Italy (Hutch/Wind) to outweigh potential risks from Iliad (new entrant). Telecom Italia´s CEO is bullish on TIM Brazil´s prospects, considering this asset to be strategic for now – although he also believes that its M&A value could be as high as 8-10x EBITDA (vs its listed value of 4-4.5x). DT´s CEO believes that benefits of scale from cross border consolidation could be reinvested in networks, but sees limited support or co-ordination from regulators. CEO Hoettges noted that DT´s US arm retained such positive commercial/financial momentum that it does not need to engage in a transaction.

PM11:42am

Actually, there's an MS wrap

PM11:42am

Ten European Telcos presented on Day 1 of TMT in Barcelona. The tone was generally upbeat on operating performance. Revenue trends are improving, cost cutting driving higher EBITDA and no indications of higher capex. FCF growth is here to stay with growing shareholder returns.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Revenue growth is back in the spotlight... For a change, after years of gloomy comments about revenue trends, this year most companies seem to be anticipating positive and sustainable revenue growth. Key drivers are network investment, data monetisation, convergence and price hikes with a value for money approach. Vodafone expects underlying H2 revenue growth to be in line with H1 with a sustained positive evolution in Germany, Italy and Spain, offsetting pressure in the UK and Italy. Telefonica is also expecting sustainable growth in Spain with better revenue trends from 4Q16 driven by price hikes in August 2016, the end of TV promotions and better B2B. Altice discussed having reignited positive turnover growth in all its properties, with Elisa highlighting revenue growth driven by unlimited data propositions. Among towers, Cellnex's increasing tenancy ratio should drive revenue growth of +4% too (with further upside from inflation). NOS also cited price hikes coming in December and an expectation to grow at +1% to +2%, above the level expected for the whole Portuguese market. Telecom Italia is confident on sustainable mobile revenue growth despite Iliad entry with fixed KPIs suggesting turnover stabilisation is close.

PM11:42am

...with cost cutting driving higher EBITDA too... Operating leverage will drive higher growth in EBITDA (than revenues). Vodafone also mentioned structural savings from shared services or network management. Telefonica claims margins should remain "at least stable" in Spain, with lower labour costs offsetting higher content costs. Both Elisa and Cellnex mentioned widening margins on efficiencies and operating leverage. TI will not cut costs if it impacts revenues, although it acknowledged that 60 call centres in Italy is too much

PM11:42am

...and sustainable and growing shareholder returns: Capex looks unlikely to rise from here, with 5G being seen as a 2020 and beyond issue, at the earliest in Europe. Telefonica and KPN expect lower capital intensity from 2017 (plateau of fiber penetration). TI expects capex to remain high until YE18, at which point it should start to decline. With the benefit of debt refinancing, FCF is expected to grow (at most companies), triggering higher dividends at Vodafone and Elisa with sustainable dividends at Telefonica.

Several management teams also noted a disconnect between Telco share price performance (YTD) and their operating performance.

11:43 am
undefined
PM11:43am

What else is there?

BE11:43am

Um ...... very little.

11:43 am
PM11:43am

I thought these Majestic numbers were a bit rubbish

PM11:44am

But maybe everyone was expecting that

Majestic Wine PLC (WINE:LSE): Last: 316.78, up 15.03 (+4.98%), High: 323.50, Low: 294.00, Volume: 482.69k
11:44 am
PM11:44am

These numbers: http://www.investe...1611170700113974P/

BE11:44am

I've lost track of the Majestic story ......

PM11:44am

· Adjusted PBT of £0.1m reflects a solid 'business as usual' performance offset by the step up in investment in H1 needed to deliver future sustainable growth

· Reported PBT was a loss of £4.4m after recognising £4.5m of adjusted items, largely relating to the Naked Wines acquisition

11:44 am
PM11:45am

Ah i see, it's brought back the dividend, regardless

PM11:45am

Uncovered

BE11:45am

Yes, lossmaking and paying a divi. Cracking.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

What even is Majestic? .... It's not a bulk-buy wine shop that sets up in suburban petrol stations any more.

PM11:45am

Is it not?

PM11:45am

The one near me is.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Took off the six-bottle limit.

PM11:45am

Ah yes

BE11:46am

It's now a US wine-club business. Which is problematic because America's weird about wine.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

In a lot of the States you still need to go to "Jerry's Liquor Mart" next door to the Walgreens .....

BE11:47am

...... Just in case the unexpected sight of a bottle of Wolfblass Yellow Label might corrupt you.

BE11:47am

Anyway, here's Peel Hunt to say "meh".

11:47 am
BE11:47am

That Majestic’s interims were going to look grim was largely
known and now absolutely everything has to fall precisely into
place in H2 for full-year numbers to be delivered. We have our
concerns as to whether that will happen. Majestic hasn’t become
a bad company overnight of course: the core bricks and mortar
business is recovering well and whilst the poor ROI number in
H1 will alarm some, Naked has terrific potential overseas.
However, forecast momentum here is flat at the very best and
from the current multiple we expect a more sideways trajectory
for the shares for now, hence our move to a HOLD

BE11:48am

"A profitless half," Jonathan Pritchard says.

BE11:48am

. It was always going to be the case that H1 would appear
becalmed in profit terms due to the heavy investment into infrastructure both at
Majestic and Naked. The problems at commercial and Naked turn a becalmed
half into poor one in profit terms. The emergence of a dividend will be solace to
some, but H2 recovery will have to be spectacular for full-year numbers to meet
hopes.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

..... and on the US business .....

BE11:48am

Naked Wine: America explained, but other issues emerge. We have been
itching for an explanation of the failure of the Direct Mail roll out in the US. It
appears that management is in mea culpa mode to a large degree (always
refreshing) as it accepts the new team could have interpreted the test data better.
Also, in certain states, the legislation dictated that the rhetoric of the
introductory offer had to change (you can’t give “free” bottles of wine away in
certain jurisdictions). This had a disastrous effect on Angel acquisition.
Management has moved on from this form of marketing now but it’s the second
major error it has made in the US and we think that the multiple would really
crumble if Naked struck out with a third. Underlying ROI was disappointing too
as a higher quality of Angel was sought, but they don’t come cheap and the
maths of such a switch meant that ROI fell from 112% last year to 58% (exdirect
mail error). It is of concern to us that management now states that last
year’s numbers were flattered by a focus on only the best ROI projects: the backup
group is clearly less potent.

BE11:49am

There are bits of America where, by law, you can't give away a free bottle of wine?!?

11:49 am
BE11:50am

There's a Land of the Free joke I could make here, but it feels too obvious.

undefined
BE11:50am

Sellside wise, there's Ophir.

11:50 am
Ophir Energy PLC (OPHR:LSE): Last: 76.75, down 0.25 (-0.32%), High: 79.25, Low: 76.25, Volume: 460.18k
PM11:50am

Steady on the right, Nately etc. We have plenty of US readers and US colleagues

BE11:50am

Double upgrade from Credit Suisse.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

On Schlumberger's flipflop buy in.

BE11:51am

Gist is that while Ophir's giving away a load of value, it at least suggests there's some value there to give away.

BE11:51am

Upgrade to Outperform (from U/P), increase TP to 100p (from 65p),
following the announcement of Schlumberger's "binding" farm-in to Fortuna.
Ophir and OneLNG (Golar Schlumberger JV) have agreed to establish a
Joint Operating Company (JOC) to develop and operate Fortuna FLNG. The
JOC will oversee the entire value chain of Fortuna, including ownership of
the upstream and midstream, and coordination of gas off-take – ownership
will be split 66.2% OneLNG 33.8% Ophir. Fortuna is effectively now an
integrated project, vs the previous tolling structure where Golar was
responsible for 100% of the midstream capex (~$1.5bn). The main barrier to
Fortuna moving forward was Golar's lack of midstream financing, so the new
ownership structure should allow Fortuna to move forward, as the new JOC
should be more readily able to secure financing, given Schlumberger's blue-
chip balance sheet, and the fact that upstream resources can now be used
as security. LNG off-take will be jointly marketed by the JOC.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Milestones before Fortuna can take FID in 1H17: i) finalisation of debt
arrangements, ii) selection of gas off-takers, iii) award of upstream &
midstream contracts, iv) Ophir shareholder approval, and v) Equatorial
Guinea (EG) Government approval. Discussions with lenders are at an
advanced stage, according to Ophir, and it is unlikely the company would
have made an announcement if it wasn't confident on the financing. Ophir
has received interest from several potential off-takers, and two consortia
have submitted bids for the upstream work, so the main uncertainty lies in
approval from the government, in our view. A key risk is that Fortuna
experiences a cost overrun, requiring additional capital from Ophir.

BE11:52am

Valuation: We set our TP broadly in line with our DCF-based risked NAV.
Our valuation now accounts for the integrated project structure of Fortuna,
with Ophir holding a 33.8% stake in the Fortuna JOC, which will remit
earnings to Ophir via dividends post first LNG. We DCF this dividend stream
to calculate our new Fortuna NAV of 46p/sh (up from 16p/sh), which also
includes the impact of raising our Fortuna project risking to 75% (from 45%).

undefined
11:53 am
PM11:53am

We havent mentioned that Yellen is speaking later

PM11:53am

I suspect she'll be looking to say as little as possible

PM11:53am

But my, whatever she does say is going to be raked over

11:53 am
PM11:53am

What's the market suggesting regarding a December hike?

PM11:54am

100% certain?

BE11:54am

The way the wind's blowing over there, I'd be saying as little as possible too ...........

11:54 am
PM11:54am

Also the Bank of Japan stuff overnight

PM11:55am

Saying they will buy unlimited amounts of paper at negative yields.

PM11:55am

So no one offered them anything at all

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Futures have nailed on a December Fed hike. 95% probability or thereabouts.

BE11:58am

Here's some Barclays FI team stuff to fill in here.

BE11:58am

At the latest FOMC meeting, the Fed upgraded the inflation backdrop and also noted that
the case for a rate hike has continued to strengthen. The data appear to be cooperating.
Nonfarm payrolls have risen c.175K/m over the past six months and various measures of
slack declined a touch at the latest payroll report. Core PCE inflation appears to have taken
another modest leg higher, to 1.7% y/y from 1.6% for most of 2016. Financial conditions
have remained benign after the unexpected Trump victory, which keeps the December hike
on the table, in our view.

11:58 am
BE11:59am

Further, recently, there has been a lot of discussion about the Fed’s reaction function prompted
by Fed Chair Yellen’s speech in which she noted that “policymakers may want to aim at being
more accommodative during recoveries than would be called for under the traditional view that
supply is largely independent of demand.” We believe the Fed’s current projected trajectory
already reflects this view. Figure 3 shows that the Fed seems to be assuming R* to persist at -
0.75% to -1% over the next few years, or 100-125bp below the current estimate of R*. This
shows that the Fed is already aiming to be more accommodative than implied by traditional
models. Hence, the Fed will likely continue to signal two hikes per year and not signal an even
shallower (or no) hiking cycle at the December meeting, in our view.

BE11:59am

Separately, while the Fed is unlikely to factor in a fiscal stimulus in its December projections,
we believe fiscal easing is likely to strengthen the case for further hikes in 2017. We
maintain our recommendation of going short 2y US Treasuries, as evolution of monetary
policy, both a Fed hike at the December meeting and no dovish shift in the reaction
function, in conjunction with fiscal easing, argue for higher front-end yields.
